date.title: Date New Date
date.subtitle: Date objects are created with the new Date() constructor. </br> There are 9 ways to create a new date object:
date.paragraph: new Date() </br>new Date(date string) </br> ew Date(year,month) </br> And after that you can add value you want or let it blank it will complete automatically. </br> new Date(year,month,day,hours,minutes,seconds,ms). In this example you can see the date now:

date.title: Date New Date(string)
date.subtitle: new Date(date string) creates a date object from a date string: September 5, 2016

date.title: Date New Date(number)
date.subtitle: new Date(year, month, ...) creates a date object with a specified date and time.

dateFormat.title: JavaScript ISO Dates
dateFormat.subtitle: ISO 8601 is the international standard for the representation of dates and times. The syntax is: (YYYY-MM-DD).
dateFormat.paragraph: is also the preferred JavaScript date format, type a year like this example: 2015-03-25

dateFormat.title: ISO Dates (Year and Month)
dateFormat.subtitle: ISO dates can be written without specifying the day (YYYY-MM):
dateFormat.paragraph: type a year like this example: 2015-03:

dateFormat.title: ISO Dates (Only Year)
dateFormat.subtitle: ISO dates can be written without month and day (YYYY):
dateFormat.paragraph: type a year like this example: 2015:

dateFormat.title: ISO Dates (Date-Time)
dateFormat.subtitle: ISO dates can be written with added hours, minutes, and seconds (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ):
dateFormat.paragraph: The example will be: 2015-03-25T12:00:00Z. </br> (Separate date and time with a capital T.Indicate UTC time with a capital Z.)

dateFormat.title: JavaScript Short Dates.
dateFormat.subtitle: Short dates are written with an "MM/DD/YYYY" syntax like this:
dateFormat.paragraph: The example will be: 03/25/2015. </br> (WARNINGS ! In some browsers, months or days with no leading zeroes may produce an error, you have to write:2015-3-25)
